did.head: Descriptive Summary
did.repository: Special Collections and Archives, James Branch Cabell Library
did.unittitle: Richmond YWCA Archives 1901-2002

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Richmond YWCA Archives, Collection Number M 373, Special Collections and Archives, James Branch Cabell Library, Virginia Commonwealth University, Richmond, Va.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: The collection was donated to the Department on March 6, 2004.

bioghist.head: Historical Information
bioghist.p: The YWCA is a national and world-wide fellowship of individuals who strive to help girls develop in all areas-- spiritually, emotionally, mentally, and physically. Principles and goals are implemented in their daily interaction with members of the organization, such as building moral character and developing leadership qualities to teach teamwork. Training girls and young women to grow in the knowledge and love of God is another characteristic that the YWCA incorporates in their daily interaction.

Among others in the meeting at St. Paul's Church in Richmond, Mrs. Emily Fairfax Whittle was the primary founder of the YWCA of Greater Richmond in May 16, 1887. Mrs. Whittle and others in the meeting wanted to help the women who left the shelter of their home to seek outside fortune. As a result of the groups concern, the association's purpose was to protect and provide help for those women who left their home. It was not until 1890 when the association was chartered and Mrs. Whittle was the first president. Several years later, the organization strengthened and was therefore able to buy two connecting houses. The houses accommodated 45 girls with shelter, a friend, and a personal touch to forge in life. By 1906, the name was amended to the Young Womens Christian Association. A progressive era of the association had developed with Hawes as president in 1911. Under her services, the Phyllis Wheatly Branch for colored women was established and they also became affiliated with the National YMCA. Activities continued to touch every type of women throughout the development of the YWCA. Since 1924, they have been a member of the United Givers Fund and many other supportive organizations that help better the nation. By 1932, the association was becoming involved in group programs for girls, such as day camps and Y-teens. In 1950, clubs were originated, such as the city wide club. Current situations that continue to influence the world or the complexities of our modern life are issues the YWCA addresses through programs and meetings.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The Collection includes minutes and records of Board committees, Board of Directors and Executive Committee, renovation records, financial records, papers on YWCA properties, staff records, organizational materials, and architectural drawings dating from 1901 to 2002.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Collection is arranged alphabetically and sometimes chronologically within each series.

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Material
separatedmaterial.p: The following items have been pulled from the collection and catalogued, and are held in Special Collections and Archives:
Boyd, Nancy. Emissaries, the Overseas work of the American YWCA 1895-1970. 1986.
Hatcher, O. Latham, Ph. D., ed. Occupations for Women: A Study made for the Southern Women's Educational Alliance. 1927.

National Board Young Women's Christian Associations. Proceedings of the Fifteenth National Convention of the Young Women's Christian Association of the United States of America. Columbus, Ohio - April 22-28, 1938. Section I Business of the Convention.
Quayle, Margaret S. As Told By Business Girls, Problems in Personal Adjustment. 1932.
Rice, Anna V. A History of the World's young Women's Christian Association. 1947.
Sims, Mary S. The Natural History of a Social Institution - The YWCA. 1936. (2 Copies)
